results.content:
If you are looking for a set of videos that are just focused just on learning HTML/CSS this set of videos are not for you. The instructor is a teacher, and you can tell he's a teacher. This means you will hear him talk about how you need to learn something that "most" webmasters don't know. He apparently believes skills most money making professionals don't need, are something you should waste your time learning, he also feels like you should be happy in your smugness to learn this obscure information. During one video he says something like "as an instructor you have to decide what to put in, and what not to put into the lessons" and "Don't show me your smart, be smart". He goes over everything from the history of the web to cryptocurrency. The videos start out agonizingly slow as he makes you pay admission to get to the useful information. My suggestion is to start with one of the 50th or so videos to save yourself some pain. 

On the flip side once you get to around video 250 or so you should expect him to start doing stuff and not explain what he's doing, or why. You can tell he's tired of doing the videos by this point and just wants to be done with it. Going so far as to say something to the effect of 'it doesn't matter if you like these I'm going to get paid anyway'. 

Pros:
Tons of depth
Very knowledgeable
Works in the real world as a webmaster
Live coding, while he talks through his thought process, is the redeeming point of this video series.

Cons:
Not focused
The outline just repeating so it's padded to make a big number of pages
He's a bit of a preachy elitist

Overall I'm glad I watched the series and chose the course. The back half of the series was worth the price of admission. I would have loved for the last 30 videos to be expanded out, and the first 70 condensed. If you enjoy gaining cursory knowledge on a subject, you should be happy. Maybe I'm just disillusioned about being a self-learner so often, but I think this could have been so much better if had spent his energy on the advanced topics and focused on HTML and CSS. (which is ironic given that he talks about how you need to be focused...)

*edit* Since taking this course a few weeks ago I've continued my study and he didn't cover accessibility at all. I feel like this is a pretty big miss. Also, he doesn't touch on embedding video or tweets with iframes. (the video section is pretty barren) As I created more complex layouts I wish he would have covered more about them, and how to preferences or industry standards. Again I feel like this is a solid foundation to HTML and CSS, but I just feel like it could have been done better.

results.content:
This course was a great introduction to the world of programming! 
Things to know:

1. This instructor is so much fun. He kept me motivated, encouraged, and entertained!
2. This is more like a semester long course than a bootcamp. He takes his time. There is a lot of good information, but he doesn't talk fast and give it to you at top speed.
3. There are a few parts that are out of date, such as the huge section on SVGs.
4. He teaches from a IDE that costs money. I used a free version and didn't have an issue.
5. This is truly the only course out there that spends this much time focusing on HTML and CSS. Most courses try to power through in a couple of hours.

If you are looking for a great course and don't need to power through in a week, I would recommend it! Thanks so much Todd, you really kept me going!

If you love hands-on-exercises after you just learnt a topic, this course comes with tons of it too to re-enforce what you just learnt.

His passion for his students is evident in how he meticulously prepares his teaching materials, his delivery when he teaches on various topics and his attention to details on areas where students commonly struggle with in the course. Did i also mention that you get a healthy dose of encouragement as you go through this course? In conclusion, if you want to master the craft of the trade aka to truly know the inner workings of HTML and CSS, TAKE THIS COURSE NOW!!!

results.content:
Todd is an excellent teacher. The value on this course is unbelievable. $12 for what would probably cost you $4000 or more in a university setting. After just a few weeks of tuning in for his videos and doing his exercises, I feel *way* more confident about my front-end programming skills. I used to be a little (oddly) afraid of html/css even though I have an extensive background in python/c/machine-learning etc. It was all just due to a lack of contact with the languages. Todd's course is so thorough and well-paced that all that fear is gone. I feel like I'm well on my way to becoming a world-class front-end (and ultimately, full-stack) web developer. 

It's also worth mentioning that Todd just seems like a great guy overall. Very humble, working hard to support his family, interested in really helping people become more than they currently are. 

Thanks for everything Todd!

results.content:
Very good stuff, and thorough to the point of physical pain ;) I'm taking the class to patch the many knowledge holes that come from being an in-between-coder at $dayjob, where quick results always trumps deep and wide knowledge, making most projects a "how quick can I google this stuff and go home".

The only minus so far is just a few minor annoyances - the constant plugging for the rather expensive subscription based Jetbrains-products, and the strange out-of-date claim towards Sublime Text. While ST is a commercial product, it is extremely stable, and also support a wider array of (heavy duty) use cases than Atom and other Electron-based editors. And when we're talking Atom, isn't that already left in the dust by VS Code by now?

Anyway, great course, and the most important thing is that we agree on leaving Adobe out in the cold :)

results.content: As a professional web engineer, even with years of experience I always watch someone else explain what I think I already know, it's that desire to always know more. With most people, they are not even wrong (google the phrase "not even wrong"). Todd is an exception to that rule, he always surprises me. Awesome to note that a sleepy Todd is better at teaching than most other wide awake instructors. One of my favorite moments in this course was watching him describe the chrome extension for highlights. On that page, the author of the extension has Orwell's essay on "Politics and the English language." (Great essay you should read it.) What Orwell says at the end of that essay is that through simplicity we achieve clarity. Confidence comes from having a clear understanding of the foundational assumptions built into products, ideas, concepts, which is very applicable for web engineering. Todd's habit of looking up actual sources of documentation gives him so much more authority to speak on things minus ego. This is ironic, given how humble and approachable he seems, and yet you see him even look up basic words to make sure he's using the correct word in the proper context. This habit of his is what makes him a great teacher. If you want to understand how to build things well, you have to understand the assumptions those technologies make. Most people give you some anecdotal trivial example based on their own usually deeply flawed experience, and preach as if it is law. Todd always checks his sources before presenting it. Of all the people who teach online, Todd is the best. Take it from a guy who spends a lot of money constantly learning online. At work, we've even adopted his habit of proving a point by pulling up the documentation to settle arguments. One of the great trademarks of a truly enlightened teacher is not hearing them say "trust me, or take me at my word." Todd always says, "let's go to the documentation and see what it says." Unfortunately for us, the documentation is usually horribly written by people who haven't read Orwell. That's where Todd's other gift comes into play. He breaks it down into simple terms that are easily understood. No regrets, you will experience deep learning and you will come out the other end, with greater clarity and more meaningful confidence. That is the ultimate respect to pay to a teacher.

results.content: Holy moly. Talk about a deep dive. You're going to need your wetsuit for this one. Truly chock full of good content, from a guy who knows his stuff, and how to teach it, and who delivers an insane amount of material. Todd's passion for the subject comes through loud and clear in each and every lesson, as does his total commitment to making sure his students - at least, those who are prepared to put in the work - come away with a deep, powerful understanding of how to do this stuff. I'm only about half way through but this could very easily turn out to be the best course I've done on udemy (and I've done a bunch). Also worth mentioning is the superb set of notes you get with this course (on Google docs), making it very easy to review the material, and the fact that Todd replies to questions promptly. Many Thanks, Todd. Outstanding job.

results.content:
This course is incredible but very long and very dense. I'm glad I have permanent access to it because I think I'll be referencing it a lot in the future. I actually showed the content list to a front end developer friend and he was mind blown. It's ridiculously false that a beginner course needs to be just rudiments and can't work its way up to real functionality. Todd will take you from explaining how to close a tag to complete responsive design and fairly advanced Flexbox and graphics, which is nuts.

Todd is also a VERY engaging teacher. He's funny and casual and goes out of his way to be positive and encouraging. I've enjoyed hanging out with him in this course and I REALLY hope he releases some more. I don't know if I care about Go atm but am considering taking his Go class just because he is such an effective teacher I feel confident I could gain the skill.

Edit: Having now gone through a couple of other Udemy courses on front end web development I keep looking back at this course and how exhaustive it is and getting salty because these other ones don't talk about Flexbox or media queries or animations or responsive design... this course is seriously a gift. There is stuff in here that literally does not exist in any other courses. Really the only thing I felt I lacked at the end was basic, even conceptual JS integration and FTP/hosting.

results.content:
First time learning coding, and it's been awesome. Todd is really inspirational, motivational, relaxed, basically everything you need for a teacher, especially if you are doing video lessons like this.

Like Todd mentions in one of his videos; a vast majority of the students might leave after watching a few lessons, which is also why the teacher plays a crucial role in how fast you learn, and if you are willing to continue learning. I am now at 37% of the course, which is at a point where you don't want to quit anymore.

Besides his skills in convincing people, his build-up in this course has been really helpful too. He starts with the basics, and learns you stuff at the right moment, at the right level. His knowledge about this subject has been really awesome, and you can see right from the beginning, that he knows what he's talking about!

One of the biggest pluses following this course, is the right balance between listening and practising. Sometimes you have to write along with Todd in order to understand the code, so you have to put in some effort, and other times, he is telling you a story, so you can sit back, relax a bit and listen to him what he has to say, but you're still learning!

One of the best teachers out there, and if you are new to coding like me, this is, at least in my opinion, the best place to gain some great knowledge and great skills about programming.

Update:

Just completed the entire course, and man, it has been a blast. I've learned so many things as a beginner, and there's so much more to learn. I am going to start a programming study this year, and Todd just gave me a head start!!

5/5

Todd without doubt knows the subject and how to teach.  He has a natural gift for explanation, for engaging with his audience, keeping them motivated, plus he's very passionate about what he's teaching.
There were times on the course when I'd think "but why?" or "what about?" and then pow! he'd provide the answer as if he read my mind. I also loved the way I could slow down or speed up the lessons to match my rate of understanding for that topic.
There must have been a mountain of time gone into learning and researching best practices in up-to-date web development to make this course (and considering the length & content included, it's a massive saving passed onto the student!).
This was my 2nd course with Todd (Golang was the other) and I've thoroughly enjoyed both. In fact, I'm off to start my 3rd course! (Web Dev with Golang)

results.content:
Nowhere on the internet do you get the absolute ground up training you get here. I checked. If you are like me and found this course after being frustrated with other resources and feeling that your just not getting it, then you have found the holy grail, you can stop looking elsewhere.

Not only is every aspect covered, but it's covered in the right time and context and the way this course is built up gradually is a piece of art. 

There are tons of exercises throughout the course and specifically because flex-box is so important there are 2 "flexbox practicum" sections just to really tighten the muscles. You get hours and hours of watching todd code it out until it's really engrained in your head.

Right now, after finishing all the lectures and exercises, I feel that I have a strong arsenal of flexbox, background, animations, fonts, colors, positions etc etc.. at my disposal and ready to launch.

Thanks so much Todd, it's been a hell of a ride!

results.content:
So far so good. I just started, but I feel like I could have used an introduction video before getting started. He jumped right into http and I had to go back and see if I missed anything.

Update: I'm on video 94 of this course and I am LOVING it. Todd really knows how to break things down into bite-sized pieces. GREAT for beginners! :)

Update 2: Once we hit Flexbox (around video 130) I started to feel like I was losing my grip on how simple things came to me. I've been using a bunch of different resources, but Flexbox has been kind of difficult for me. I'm wondering if there has been some kind of update since these were recorded or if they've implemented an easier method...

Update 3: Video 197 @ 4 min... me too bro, me too! :D Also, after taking a much needed break, Flex-Box kind of just clicked for me now?... Make sure you take your breaks! They really do work miracles!
